items.title: Toy loon becomes unofficial mascot for Canadian women's Olympic hockey team
items.summary_auto: A toy loon from a fan has become a mascot, or possibly a good luck charm, for Canada's women's hockey team at Milano Cortina 2026.

items.title: Canada has officially joined the EU's loans-for-weapons program
items.summary_auto: Defence Minister David McGuinty says Canada has now officially joined the European Union’s Security Action for Europe (SAFE) program, which offers loans to member states to invest in defence capabilities.

items.title: Take the tunnel, Windsor city councillor says as Ambassador Bridge owners lobby against new bridge
Zelenskyy says U.S. too often asks Ukraine, not Russia, for concessions, ahead of Geneva peace talks
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy voiced hope on Saturday that U.S.-brokered peace talks in Geneva next week would be substantive, but he said Ukraine was being asked "too often" to make concessions.

items.title: Russia is still waging war in Ukraine, but door opening for more of its athletes to compete
items.summary_auto: Twenty athletes from Russia and Belarus are competing at the Winter Olympics as neutral. Moscow has asked for its athletes to be fully reinstated in international competition, and sporting bodies are beginning to open the door to those once completely banned from participating.

items.title: An estimated 350,000 people march in Toronto in support of Iran protests, police say
items.summary_auto: A rally in North York Saturday that drew an estimated 350,000 people called on the Canadian government to recognize Iran's exiled crown prince Reza Pahlavi as the leader of Iran’s democratic transition after anti-government protests erupted in Iran at the end of last year.

items.title: From umbrella to uncertainty: Europe and Canada's nuclear deterrence anxiety
2 Toronto teachers on leave after racist social media messages discovered: School board
items.summary_auto: Two teachers have been put on leave from a North York high school, as the Toronto Catholic District School Board investigates an exchange of racist messages on a shared school program's social media account.

items.title: Why Tumbler Ridge is resilient
items.summary_auto: The town at the centre of a national tragedy has faced collapse and hardship but continues to persevere.

items.title: Alexei Navalny was poisoned by Kremlin with dart frog toxin, European nations say
items.summary_auto: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned by the Kremlin with a lethal toxin derived from the skin of poison dart frogs, five European countries said Saturday.

items.title: Amid 'Buy Canadian' fervour, Canada's top pension funds still heavily invested in U.S.
Youth hockey ref escorted out of N.S. rink by police after 'hate-motivated' harassment, say RCMP
items.summary_auto: A hockey game in Musquodoboit Harbour, N.S., had to be stopped and a young referee was escorted out of the arena by police after the official was targeted by hate-motivated verbal assaults from a person in the crowd, say RCMP.

items.title: Being Jamaican in Canada meant we didn’t talk about mental health — until depression forced me to
items.summary_auto: When Bria Barrows was diagnosed with depression as a high school student, her family struggled to talk about mental health issues. Since then, she has learned that talking leads to healing.

items.title: Cheating, a proposal, cute couples — but are the Olympics really the place for love?
items.summary_auto: Love often seems to be in the air during the Olympics. And there's a storied history of Olympic declarations of love, Olympic couples, and the sometimes controversial Olympic proposal.

items.title: Head of military's space division warns Russia is considering putting nuclear weapons in orbit
items.summary_auto: The head of Canada's military space division says the country "should absolutely be" concerned about Russia's potential capabilities amid global fears the Kremlin is considering putting nuclear weapons in place to target satellites.

items.title: Are you an early bird or a night owl? Why scientists are moving beyond these groupings
items.summary_auto: Categorizing people into just two groups — late and early risers — may be oversimplified when it comes to health and behaviour.

items.title: Bart Layton didn't like Chris Hemsworth for Crime 101. Then he proved him wrong
items.summary_auto: Coming after his critically acclaimed documentary The Imposter, and genre-defying American Animals, director Bart Layton just released his deceptively deep heist film Crime 101. While he didn't initially believe Chris Hemsworth could pull off the role, he told CBC the Australian actor proved him wrong.

items.title: Does your local school lock its doors? Why school entrance protocols vary across Canada
items.summary_auto: This week's tragedy in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., and  other intruder incidents in schools are reviving conversations across Canada about school safety — including controlled access and entry procedures.

items.title: Inuit leaders urge Ottawa to follow Greenland's infrastructure lead
items.summary_auto: Inuit leaders back from a recent trip to Greenland say there's a stark contrast between the infrastructure in that Nordic country compared to Canada's North, and they're calling on the federal government to urgently fill the gap as part of its enhanced focus on Arctic security.

items.title: ‘We’re so vulnerable’: How Canadians can cope with anxiety in the face of existential threats from the U.S.
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump’s second term has threatened Canada with annexation and economic ruin, leaving some Canadians feeling anxious and concerned. A Winnipeg therapist offers strategies for coping with those emotions.

items.title: Winter slips can be especially dangerous for seniors. This Quebec judo school teaches them how to fall safely
items.summary_auto: Dojo Blainville has designed a program for seniors to help prevent injury in the case of a fall.

items.title: From Heated Rivalry to Wuthering Heights, book-to-screen adaptations cause a boom in book sales
items.summary_auto: Canadian booksellers are noticing that sales for book-to-screen adaptations are now having a moment like never before. Booksellers say that social media fandoms and streaming services are driving this phenomenon.

items.title: Mario Tennis Fever doesn't change the formula much, but rallies are so good it barely matters
items.summary_auto: Mario Tennis Fever stays true to a formula as solid as it was on the Nintendo 64 decades ago: best played on a couch with friends.
